awd_titl_txt: Embodying Emotion in Interaction:  A Biocultural-Linguistic Study of Communication and Physiology
awd_abstract_narration:
Personal relationships are often a source of comfort and support, but they can also be a source of stress and conflict. Previous laboratory and self-report research indicates that communication between partners is predictive of relational satisfaction and well-being. It also demonstrates that relational behaviors are linked to physical responses in the body that impact both short- and long-term health, and suggests that everyday emotion-laden communication between intimate partners influences physical outcomes and that, in turn, physical responses concurrently influence communication. We only have limited understanding, however, of what this relationship between communication, emotion, and the body looks like on a day-to-day basis, and on how this process differs in relation to racial, socioeconomic, and other cultural pressures influencing different couples. Therefore, understanding the multi-directional processes through which culture, communication, and physiological regulation co-emerge, outside of the laboratory and in specific emotion-laden interactions between intimate partners at home, can lead to more developed scientific understanding about how interpersonal behavior and physical wellbeing are connected. Findings from this research will provide insight into how communication between partners functions as a mediator of both intermediate and long-term effects on wellbeing. Ultimately, this research has implications for individual, relational, and societal health and wellbeing. At the University of Alabama, the project also contributes to the development of a new interdisciplinary program, and the training of both graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities.

Drs. Sonya Pritzker, Jason DeCaro, and Joshua Pederson of the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa will develop innovative theoretical and methodological models for understanding how the human body affects and is affected by everyday communication in the context of culture. The purpose of this research is to provide evidence for the ways that regular co-constructed patterns of emotion communication relate to physiological outcomes, ultimately affecting psychosocial wellbeing among couples in everyday life. The research thus takes an ethnographic approach to the study of relating among adult partners in the Southeastern U.S., emphasizing naturalistic observation, video-recoding, in-depth interviews, and close monitoring of physiological activity over multiple days. The researchers aim to collect anthropologically sound evidence for the reciprocal ways moment-to-moment physiology is affected by and affects emotion communication in everyday life, and how this process impacts indicators of psychosocial wellbeing among partners. The overarching intellectual merit of this research is the development of theoretical frameworks and methodological tools for innovative research programs examining intersections between language, culture, and the human body in multiple settings. This project thus brings together disparate subfields of anthropology and related disciplines, contributes to psychological understandings about the dynamics of emotions, and provides unprecedented insight into the ways in which everyday communication among intimate partners is linked to physiological processes. Building on the findings from laboratory studies, this project further addresses the complex layers of culture and communication in relationships within everyday lived experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This multi-year study captured everyday interactions between romantic partners in their homes to study how communication and bodies intertwine and simultaneously influence one another. Previous research has suggested a strong link between interaction and various physiological processes. However, prior studies have mostly been laboratory-based, rarely conducting naturalistic observations in couples' home environments. This led us to hypothesize that multiple types of emotion communication would be associated with physiological regulation in and across repeated interactions. The current project sought to extend scientific understanding of emotion-laden interactions in the context of a couple's natural habitat. In contrast with previous studies that focus on 1-2 short interactions (usually around 10 minutes), this project has also offered data consisting of multiple, extended interactions over several days. This cross-subfield, interdisciplinary, ethnographic approach, finally, enlarged previous researchers' emphasis on classifying emotion communication in terms of discrete emotions and particular "types" of interaction (e.g., conflict, affiliation, etc.) Instead, this study embraced the complexity of synchronized analysis of verbal and nonverbal communication with physiological functioning to demonstrate the ways in which both emotion and embodied experience co-emerge in real-time interactions.

This project has led to a range of findings that have been presented at various academic conferences including American Anthropological Association, Society for Psychological Anthropology, and the International Association for Relationships Research. A book chapter and academic article under review further showcase the findings from this study. Various public presentations about the methods and findings of this study have occurred at several universities including University of California-Los Angeles, University of Virginia, and the University of Alabama. Specifically, we have shown how, rather than consistent patterns as often previously assumed, physiological measures associated with communicative encounters measured in the context of intimate relationships demonstrated multiple, shifting, and variable patterns. No couple in our study, for example, showed consistent patterns regarding the way their bodies "synchronize" (or do not) with one another in interaction. We showed, rather, that individuals' communicative behaviors can create heart-rate patterns that can align, diverge, or follow with their partner, creating a temporary pattern that might shift in another, similar interaction later that day or the following day. Our findings prompt further examination of how the dynamic variations in bidirectional associations between interaction and physiology are mediated by events and encounters that each partner has experienced in the recent and/or remote past. Based on the data collected for this study, we have nevertheless repeatedly demonstrated how linguistic anthropological analysis is enhanced by the analysis of concurrent psychophysiological data and vice versa. This has further offered a richer, more grounded understanding of the ways that even seemingly mundane interactions between romantic partners mediate the emotional, psychological, and physical well-being of each individual as well as the couple overall.

Overall, this study showcased the value of considering the nuanced, layered, and multi-faceted contributions of various systems involved in the human experience. Considering both linguistic meaning-making and biological processes, for example, the current study specifically advanced an innovative "biolinguistic" model for understanding intimate human behavior. This cross-disciplinary and cross-subfield model has already contributed to multiple investigations by graduate students, as well as it formed the basis of Dr. Pritzker's successful NSF CAREER proposal. We are thus confident that future studies in anthropology and beyond can capitalize on this methodological model to understand social processes in various contexts.
